awd_abstract_narration:
People have long been fascinated with spoken language, one of the most salient traits that defines human beings as unique. Language, by its very nature, is prone to change for both cognitive and social reasons. The study of language variation -- how and why it changes, and the fact that an earlier form of the language can be reconstructed based on evidence from its daughters -- is therefore a primary way to understand the cultural history of its speakers. Since the principles of variation, change, and reconstruction methodology can be applied to any group of related languages, the insight gleaned from studying one particular language family can be extrapolated to all others around the globe. When combined with the increasingly rapid advances being made in human language technology, this knowledge is crucial to facilitating American understanding of other cultures, developing new language-based technologies, and remaining technologically competitive in an increasingly interconnected world.

The goal of this project is the reconstruction of the Kam-Sui branch of the Kra-Dai language phylum of Southeast Asia, a region in which the Principle Investigator, Dr. Peter Norquest (University of Arizona), has extensive experience. Recent publications, primarily by native and Chinese fieldworkers, make this an attainable goal in a way that has not been possible previously. The research will build on the already completed reconstructions of two sister branches, Proto Tai and Proto Hlai, explicating the historical relationships between them and allowing the inference of  demographic expansions in prehistory. It comprises a significant step toward completing a top-level reconstruction of Proto Kra-Dai, which will in turn allow testing the Austro-Tai hypothesis, which postulates a genetic relationship between Austronesian and Kra-Dai. Since the nature of the relationships between the five primary language phyla of Southeast Asia has been a longstanding topic of debate amongst historical linguists, this project will also benefit scholars working on the other three language phyla of the region (Sino-Tibetan, Austroasiatic, and Hmong-Mien), as historical contact will be made amenable to a more refined analysis than has previously been possible. The commitment by the Center for Research on Computational Linguistics (CRCL) to grant advance access to their Kam-Sui database will enable the goals of this project to be rapidly achieved; the reconstructions resulting from this project will then be merged into a more extensive online repository to be made available to the public via the online interface at sealang.net. Both the reconstructions and the practical and theoretical insights gleaned from the project will be released in a series of publications.

por.por_cntn:
The study of language variation – how and why language changes, and the fact that an earlier form of a language can be reconstructed based on the evidence of its daughters – is a primary way to understand the cultural history of its speakers. Since the principles of variation, change, and reconstruction methodology can be applied to any group of related languages, the insight gleaned from studying one particular language family can be extrapolated to all others around the globe, particularly when they share certain typological characteristics. When combined with the increasingly rapid advances being made in human language technology, this knowledge is crucial to facilitating American understanding of other cultures and remaining technologically competitive in an increasingly interconnected world.

This project is concerned with the reconstruction of the Kam-Sui branch of the Kra-Dai language phylum of Southeast Asia, and with the resolution of a long-standing question about whether two Kam-Tai subgroups, Biao and Lakkja, are part of the Kam-Sui branch or coordinate with it. Recent publications, primarily by native and Chinese fieldworkers, made this an attainable goal in a way that had not been possible until recently. Our research builds on the previously completed reconstructions of two sister branches, Proto-Tai and Proto-Hlai, attempting to bring their phylogenetic status relative to Kam-Sui into sharper resolution within Kam-Tai, thereby shedding light on demographic expansions in prehistory; it also represents a significant step toward completing a top-level reconstruction of Proto-Kra-Dai. The future reconstruction of Proto-Kra-Dai will in turn allow the direct comparison for the first time of this phylum with Proto-Austronesian, testing the Austro-Tai hypothesis first proposed by Paul Benedict which postulates a genetic relationship between Austronesian and Kra-Dai.

Specific outcomes of this project include:

(1) The establishment of the eastern half of a Kam-Tai phylogenetic tree which includes all Biao, Lakkja, and Kam-Sui subgroups and languages, and is grounded in reconstructed forms at each level (see Eastern Kam-Tai Phylogeny). Sound changes and semantic shifts are articulated at all levels of the tree and serve as evidence for the decisions made in constructing this tree (see Etymology Sample).

(2) The relationships of the Biao and Lakkja subgroups (which were unclear in previous literature) to the Kam-Sui family have been established. These are shown to be archaic Kam-Tai groups which precede both the Kam-Sui and Tai families within the Kam-Tai phylogenetic tree. This serves to underscore the importance of additional future fieldwork on these two subgroups, particularly Biao, which has considerable internal diversity and which roots the Kam-Tai phylogenetic tree within Kra-Dai.

(3) A new hypothesis of Kam-Tai language dispersal, rooted at the Pearl River Delta and following riverine trajectories beginning in Gu?ngd?ng Province and proceeding into Gu?ngx?, Guìzh?u and Húnán Provinces, has been made possible by comparing the phylogenetic language tree with a topographical map of China (see Kam-Tai Dispersal). Post-disperal contact relationships between certain subgroups and/or languages are elucidated under this hypothesis and provide further evidence for it.

(4) Important distinctions have been demonstrated to exist in the Proto-Kam-Sui phonological inventory, including (a) an opposition between an alveolar and retroflex series of consonants, (b) an opposition between a velar and a uvular series of consonants, and (c) a distinction between plain and palatalized consonants.

(5) A website (http://sealang.net/project/kd/norquest/) is housed at CRCL. It currently showcases a sample of our research, and will eventually display all of the data from our project. It additionally hosts a Google Map with the locations plotted for all languages currently in our database (see Eastern Kam-Tai Map) as well as a graphic of the postulated Eastern Kam-Tai migration route superimposed upon a map of the Pearl River Basin. We have prepared and loaded ten sample etymological sets for the purposes of this report which are representative of the entirety of the data which we will be finalizing and publishing in batches over the upcoming months.

Since the nature of the relationships between the five primary language phyla of Southeast Asia has been a longstanding topic of debate amongst historical linguists, this project also benefits scholars working on the other four language phyla of the region (Sino-Tibetan, Austroasiatic, Hmong-Mien, and Austronesian), as historical contact will be made amenable to a more refined analysis than has previously been possible. The commitment by the Center for Research on Computational Linguistics (CRCL) to grant access to their Kam-Sui database has enabled the goals of this project to be achieved in a realistic way. The reconstructions resulting from this project are being made available to the public via sealang.net; both the reconstructions and the practical and theoretical insights gleaned from the project will be released in a series of future publications.
